headline.main: For Teresa Heinz Kerry, Food Is Personal and Political

docs.abstract: Profile of Teresa Heinz Kerry focusing on her knowledge and opinions about food and nutrition; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: AT lunchtime in a grand old house surrounded by maples just beginning to turn, the fragrances wafting from the kitchen where Teresa Heinz Kerry taught her three sons to cook were so tempting it was difficult to concentrate on the expressionist paintings from the 1960's on the walls of the living room. The source of the tantalizing aromas was one of Mrs. Heinz Kerry's favorite dishes, a fish soup. It was simmering on a Wolf stove in a kitchen filled with all the modern accouterments of the serious cook: a huge center island with a granite top, a Sub-Zero refrigerator; copper pots hanging from the ceiling. A rosemary bush sat on a table inlaid with old blue and white Portuguese tiles.
docs.snippet: The wife of the Democratic candidate for president talks as knowledgeably about food safety as she does about classic French sauces.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: Eating Giant Awakens

docs.abstract: China's Deputy Health Minister Wang Longde reports that number of obese people in China has doubled to 60 million from 1992 to 2002; warns problem will get worse (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The number of obese people in China doubled to 60 million people from 1992 to 2002, with diseases related to an unhealthy diet and way of life also on the rise, the government said. China's first comprehensive national survey on diet, nutrition and diseases found that a 7.1 percent of adults were classified as obese and that 22.8 percent -- about 200 million of China's population of around 1.3 billion -- were overweight, Wang Longde, the deputy health minister, told a news conference, warning that the problem would get worse. ''The Chinese population does not have enough awareness and lacks knowledge of what is a reasonable nutrition and diet,'' he said. Having themselves suffered from inadequate food in their youth, grandparents and parents often stuff young children with excessive amounts of food. Less physical activity -- with fewer Chinese having to do physical labor for a living and many now driving cars instead of cycling or walking -- has also contributed to the problems of overweight, obesity, diabetes and abnormal blood lipid levels, the study found.
docs.snippet: The number of obese people in China doubled to 60 million people from 1992 to 2002, with diseases related to an unhealthy diet and way of life also on the rise, the government said. China's first comprehensive national survey on diet, nutrition and...

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: Other Benefits Of Obesity Surgery

docs.abstract: Analysis of 136 studies finds surgery for obesity can also cure patients' diabetes, high blood pressure and high cholesterol, apparently altering body chemistry and elminating or relieving conditions that could lead to heart attacks, stroke and kidney failure; analysis, financed by Johnson & Johnson unit, appears in Journal of American Medical Association (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Surgery for obesity can also cure patients' diabetes, high blood pressure and high cholesterol, according to an analysis of 136 studies. The research found that such operations appear to alter body chemistry, and eliminate or relieve conditions that can lead to heart attacks, stroke and kidney failure. The analysis, which appears in The Journal of the American Medical Association, was financed by a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson that develops and sells surgical instruments, including staplers for obesity surgery. But the results echo what many doctors have reported.
docs.snippet: Surgery for obesity can also cure patients' diabetes, high blood pressure and high cholesterol, according to an analysis of 136 studies. The research found that such operations appear to alter body chemistry, and eliminate or relieve conditions that...

headline.main: Snooze Alarm Takes Its Toll on a Nation

docs.abstract: Sleep researchers agree that short periods of sleep are not as effective as sustained sleep; hold that dozing and waking, from repeated use of snooze alarm, causes shifts in brain-wave patterns; Dr Timothy Roehrs, Henry Ford Hospital Sleep Disorders and Research Center research director, leads study published in journal Sleep that measures effects of limited sleep on mental and physical abilities; decision-making, memory, creativity, attitude and overall health are found to be negatively impacted by sleep deprivation; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: When his clock-radio goes off at 7 a.m., David Epstein's latest wake-up strategy roars into high gear: he stumbles out of bed, walks across the room and pushes the snooze button. Then he climbs between the sheets. A few minutes later, his travel clock rings. He presses snooze and rolls over for more sleep -- until the alarm on his BlackBerry goes off. Sitting up, he punches keys to reset it for 10 more minutes, then it's back to the pillow.
docs.snippet: Is a bumpy arousal from sleep a way to recoup much-needed sleep? Or is it a recipe for exhaustion?

headline.main: Child Deaths Are Up in City, With Many Occurring in Bed

docs.abstract: Child fatalities in New York City are increasing, driven in part by surge in number of parents who roll over on their infants while sleeping in same bed; 58 children died in first nine months of 2004, as compared to 2002 and 2003, when 54 died each year (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Child fatalities in New York City are increasing, city officials said yesterday, driven at least in part by a surge in the number of parents who rolled over on their infants while sleeping in the same bed. Fifty-eight children, age 14 days to 16 years, died in the first nine months of this year, compared with 37 in the same period in 2003. Already more children have died in 2004 than in all of 2003 or 2002, when 54 died each year, records show. Still, the number of children who have died this year is far less than the 130 who died in 1988, a peak year, city records show.
docs.snippet: Child fatalities in New York City are increasing, city officials said yesterday, driven at least in part by a surge in the number of parents who rolled over on their infants while sleeping in the same bed.
